newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Thakral confident of Singapore $ listing.
newsitem.headline: Thakral confident of Singapore $ listing.

text.p: Consumer electronic products distributor Thakral Corp Ltd, which saw six month net profits up 20 percent, said on Tuesday it was confident it would meet the requirements for a Singapore dollar listing.
The company, which also distributes audio-visual products from JVC, Panasonic, Sharp and Sony, is currently listed in US dollars on the Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES).

"Internally with a slight restructure, we will be able to meet the criteria," said managing director Inderbethal Singh Thakral at a news conference announcing the company's six months results to September 30, 1996.
"We hope to put a package to SES to see if it accepts," Thakral said, adding that the proposal would be made within this year.
Thakral said one of the criteria, yet unfulfilled, was for the Economic Development Board of Singapore to extend the company's Operational Headquarters status to 10 years from five years.

The company said the extraordinary loss of S$2.85 million incurred by associate company, Wearnes Thakral Pte Ltd, included prior period expenses of S$1.41 million and costs related to cessation of manufacturing activities and restructuring.
Thakral said the company would now concentrate on distributing IBM products in Malaysia and looked to distributing more computer products within the region where Wearnes Thakral has a better market.

On Friday, Thakral announced its net profits for the six months ended September 30 rose 20 percent to Singapore $28.67 million, while turnover eased to S$552.09 million from S$568.97 million. Pre-tax profits rose 18.5 percent to S$34.86 million.
Thakral attributed the improvement in pre-tax profits to better sourcing of products and improved margins as a result of bulk distributions to a wider range of customers.
Thakral said the company was likely to maintain margins for the second half and was looking to increase turnover as the economy picks up.
"We expect losses incurred will be arrested...We expect better increment from Wearnes Thakral itself," Thakral said, adding that in the second half a small loss from Wearnes is still expected.
Thakral said the company would continue to focus on manufacturing and distributing consumer electronic products in Hong Kong and China.
Hong and China contribute 55 percent and 40 percent respectively to the company's turnover and 96 percent and four percent respectively to its pre-tax profit.

Thakral said its direct investment division will continue to concentrate on non-core investments like property. Thakral added that by March net year, the company would have used up its US$25 million budget set aside for non-core investment.
